raw_text:
Original Exorcist to be screened
 
 The original version of horror prequel Exorcist: The Beginning, dropped by producers over claims it was not scary enough, is to have its world premiere.
 
 The film, directed by Paul Schrader, will be screened on 18 March at the International Festival of Fantastic Film in Brussels. The psychological drama stars Stellan Skarsgard and foreruns the 1973 film. Schrader was replaced by director Renny Harlin who made a new version of the film which debuted in 2004. The prequel project was originally announced in 2001, with actor Liam Neeson in the lead role and John Frankenheimer as director. However Frankenheimer pulled out in 2002, a month before he died.
 
 Skarsgard then replaced Neeson in the role of Father Merrin, made famous by Max Von Sydow in the 1973 film. Principal footage was shot in Morocco and Rome at a reported cost of $32m. However, in August 2003 it emerged that producers Morgan Creek were shelving Schrader's version of the film, having complained it was not scary enough. As well as replacing Schrader with Harlin - the director behind Die Hard 2 and Cliffhanger - the producers also changed most of the cast, but Swedish star Skarsgard stayed in the Merrin role. Harlin's film, released in the UK in October 2004, received lukewarm reviews but went on to make over $76m (£40.7m) worldwide. The festival screening will be the first time that Schrader's film has been seen in public. Reports that it will be released either in cinemas or on DVD have yet to be confirmed. Other films at the festival in the Belgium capital, which runs from 11-26 March, include the US horror hit Boogeyman and the forthcoming sequel Ring 2, as well as a selection of films adapted from the works of Jules Verne.
llama3.2:1b: The original Exorcist prequel film "Exorcist: The Beginning" is to premiere at an international festival in Brussels on March 18th. Directed by Paul Schrader, it stars Stellan Skarsgard as Father Merrin and was originally announced in 2001 but changed its director multiple times before finally being completed by Renny Harlin.

Producers shelved Schrader's version due to it not being scary enough, leading to director Renny Harlin replacing him, but ultimately resulting in a successful worldwide box office performance of over $76m.

qwen2.5:0.5b: The Exorcist: The Beginning film is to be screened at the International Fantastic Film Festival in Brussels on March 18th, 2005. It stars Stellan Skarsgard and features a psychological drama adaptation of the 1973 horror classic. Production costs were reported to be $32 million but the film was shelved by producers Schrader and Harlin after replacing them with Renny Harlin. The director, John Frankenheimer, has been replaced with Stellan Skarsgard in the role of Father Merrin. The festival screening will feature a prequel version of the Exorcist: The Beginning that was originally announced in 2001 but later shelved due to concerns about it not being scary enough. Reports suggest the film could be released either in cinemas or on DVD, with other films from the Belgium capital including Boogeyman, Ring and sequel Ring 2, as well as a selection of adaptations of Jules Verne's works.

Other films at the festival in Belgium, which runs from 11-26 March, include the US horror hit Boogeyman and the forthcoming sequel Ring 2, as well as a selection of films adapted from the works of Jules Verne.

tinyllama:1.1b: The original version of horror prequel Exorcism: The Beginning, directed by Paul Schradeer, will have its world premier at the International Festival of Fantastic Film in Bruxelles on March 18th. Despite claims that it was not scary enough, the film is set to be relased after being screened at the festival, with Liam Neeseon replacing Steffan Skarsgard as Father Merrin, making a new version of the original film by John Frankenheimer. tinydolphin:1.1b:
In January, rumors circulated that the original version of the horror prequel Exorcist: The Beginning would be screened at the International Festival of Fantastic Film in Brussels, scheduled to take place on March 18th. Directed by Paul Schrader, the film starred Stellan Skarsgard and was supposed to premiere in 2004. However, this film project was later replaced by director Renny Harlin, who made a new version of the film with an updated cast. The prequel had already received lukewarm reviews before being revised, prompting concerns from producers over whether it was scary enough for audiences.

In August 2003, it was announced that Morgan Creek Productions, which acquired the rights to the film in 2001, were considering shelving Schrader's version of the movie due to its perceived lack of scares. As a result, several actors, including Stellan Skarsgard and John Frankenheimer, lost their roles in the film.

The new cast included Swedish actor Liam Neeson, who was initially expected to play Father Merrin before replacing Skarsgard. Principal footage was shot in Morocco and Rome, with additional scenes taken in New York. The film's producers reportedly complained that the film was not scary enough and decided to change their minds by shelving Schrader's version of the movie.

In March 2004, it was reported that the original film would be screened at the Brussels International Festival of Fantastic Film, followed by a DVD release. The festival screening will mark the first public appearance of Schrader's film. Other films at the event include the US horror hit Boogeyman and the forthcoming sequel Ring 2.

granite3.1-dense:2b: The original Exorcist prequel, "Exorcist: The Beginning," directed by Paul Schrader in 2001, will have its world premiere at the International Festival of Fantastic Film in Brussels on March 18. The film, starring Stellan Skarsgard as Father Merrin (a role previously held by Max Von Sydow), was shelved due to its lack of scares. Director Renny Harlin took over after replacing Schrader in 2003. Principal photography cost $32 million, primarily in Morocco and Rome.
